298: Black Lotus.author: infernox10
298: Black Lotus.text_parsed:
Let's put it in a way that modern (August 2010) players can understand.
1 in opening hand, including land drop: Vampire Nocturnus (yay vampire tribal -.-)
2 in opening hand, including land drop: hell, any 7 CMC card to be sure. Akroma's Memorial to name a fantastic one, on turn 1.
3 in opening hand, including land drop: Kozilek, Butcher of Truth, Progenitus, Storm Herd on turn 1.
4 in opening hand, including land drop: Well, there aren't any 13 CMC cards out there,
But go crazy on the spells if you got 4 in your opening hand.
The point is, this card puts you several steps ahead of your opponent with no drawback.
This is, single-handedly, the best card in the game.
It can go into any deck without ever hindering it or being a dead draw (even late game, where you can summon big baddies and still have mana to play abilities, ehoes, etc.
Those who say this card is lackluster/bad/not that great/okay simply don't understand how wonderful it is.
And this is why I have to make a list.

298: Black Lotus.author: scumbling1
298: Black Lotus.text_parsed:
"Can someone explain to me why the Beta Black Lotus is (as of this post) rated lower than Lotus Bloom?!"

I think there is a disconnect for some people between Black Lotus's reputation & price tag and it's actual ability. I've been there myself, thinking in my beginning days "Why is this the most expensive card in Magic? My Dark Rituals are dirt cheap, and not that much worse. Shouldn't the most expensive card in the game do something more flashy?" From that perspective, it's easy to imagine a lot of players thinking of Black Lotus as overrated and not worth the price tag. A card as (in)famous as Black Lotus really needs to impress to live up to it's reputation, and a less-experienced player could easily overlook it as a card that 'just produces mana'.

298: Black Lotus.author: Shadoflaam
298: Black Lotus.text_parsed:
I have a friend who is utterly convinced that this and Ancestral Recall are actually quite bad, and that they are worth 100$ max. If I didn't lose my arm strength in exchange for MTG skillz, I'd punch him in the face until he got that THIS IS SO MUCH FREE MANA THERE IS LITERALLY NOTHING TO COMPARE THIS TO. Geosurge is the only somewhat-comparable card I can think of right now, which provides a bonus of 3 mana... on turn 4, in monored, with restrictions. This does the same on turn 1, in any deck, no restrictions. You wanna play that Phyrexian Obliterator, but you have a Swamp, Island, Plains, Forest, Mountain, the Obliterator, and this in your hand? Go ahead, hell do it TURN 1. Madness. This is worth AT LEAST 1k. BUT, I do think it is overpriced, as I would never pay more than 60$ for a card, and $3000 for a card restricted in Vintage? Meaning I have to buy 55 other $100+ cards? No thanks, I'll pass.
Final: 50/5. The. Best. Card. In. The. Game. With the possible exceptions of Ancestral Recall or (I'm gonna say it, don't hurt me please) Jace, the Mind Sculptor, SOLELY because if you had a deck with only land and Lotuses/Recalls it would suck but a deck with only lands and Jace could at least survive a bit longer.

298: Black Lotus.author: DarthParallax
298: Black Lotus.text_parsed:
Force of Will is the Magic reason why many people who think this card is overrated.....ARE ABSOLUTELY RIGHT.

The reason why it is so poweful is it's ability to enable such stupid possiblities as:

Turn 1: Swamp, Dark Ritual, Dark Ritual, Buried Alive (3 Phyrexian Obliterators), Dark Ritual, Entomb (4th Obliterator), Dark Ritual, Living End.

Yeah, that's a legit move in Vintage. And there are so much more reliable way to completely destroy the heck out of someone on Turn 1 than 'JUST' four Phyrexian Obliterators.

So, for Combotastic Potential, it LOOKS like it's worth 5 stars, right? Well, if you made a whole class of par-excellence cards worth 5, then yes. But it is not worth '5.1' stars- i.e. it's not the best card in the game.

Because there IS a situation where it's a dead draw- the part of the game where you can't combo out.
If your combo is stopped by anything, Black Lotus becomes a dead card, because the normal 'pro' resources: drawing cards, extra mana, extra turns: stop being good as the natural, instinctive Timmy resources: Attack points, bodies for blocking, life points, or at least spells that create more damage/life loss/attack points in some way.

It doesn't affect the board. You shouldn't NEED anything else if you draw it in your opening hand, but if you are in the mid- to late- game because someone Force of Will'd you, and you draw this, you might well be thinking you'd rather have drawn something else- Time Walk in an otherwise 'dead' game is at least '1U: draw a card', and gives you the chance to draw something that can actually win.

Make no mistake, for sheer Potential, Black Lotus outstrips every card in the game- but the 'every deck, every situation, no drawbacks' thing people keep going on about? that's not true-

because this is why we have Blue. Blue gives even Black Lotus a drawback.

between Ancestral Recall and Time Walk, Recall gives more cards for less mana, but Time Walk does so much more than just draw cards for only 1 additional mana, especially if you have permanents of any kind out.

1. Time Walk- useful at any point in the game
2. Black Lotus- it DOES go in any deck, useful in the early game for making sure there's no late game.
3. Ancestral Recall- Time Walk is more worth splashing Blue for, since this can sometimes feel like Black Lotus. drawing cards with no mana to play them is like having lots of mana with no cards to play, and it's not colorless.

These 3 cards will be the topic of Magic debate for pretty much ever. Accept that a consensus will not happen, and that people's Top 3 will be in different orders. But these are the Big Three, period.

298: Black Lotus.author: HeraldOfRazia
298: Black Lotus.text_parsed: 5/5 obviously, now that we've gotten that out of the way. I see a lot of people comment on these kinds of cards with "what were they thinking printing this?" or "It's totally broken any way you look at it, surely they would have seen that when making the card." The answer lies in the very simple fact that the game was new. The main reason why this card and the Moxes are so good is because we are comparing it to all other 14,000+ cards in Magic. Back when the game first started it wasn't as much of a big deal of having 3 mana on turn 1 simply because the options of cards to play were so limited.

302: Clockwork Beast.author: majinara
302: Clockwork Beast.text_parsed:
Those clockwork creatures are a nice idea for sure, and 7 power for 6 mana (on the first attack) ain't horrible.
Still, it's far too clunky. All the fuss of having to spend mana and to tap it only during upkeep to rewind it, so you can't attack or block that turn. And you can't even put more counters on it that it started with... If it would have trample, or needn't to tap to rewind, or whatever, it would be playable. But like this, it's a fun idea and nostalgic card, but in matters of power level nearly useless.

302: Clockwork Beast.author: nibelheim_valesti
302: Clockwork Beast.text_parsed:
Played this a lot back in the day. Can't remember once winding it up.

Think it through - Swing once, it's ahead of a Craw Wurm. Swing twice, still ahead of a Craw Wurm. Swing three times, level with a Craw Wurm... and you've done 18 damage. They're dead. Games don't last long enough for the "winding down" thing to often cause problems, it's just good flavor.

Even if for some reason you're trying to kill them wholely with this you'd still finish them with your fourth swing. Plus it's immune to terror - which Craw Wurm most certainly is not.

306: Cyclopean Tomb.author: luca_barelli
306: Cyclopean Tomb.text_parsed: Is it just me or is that Oracle text way more confusing than it needs to be?
306: Cyclopean Tomb.text_posted: Is it just me or is that Oracle text way more confusing than it needs to be?

306: Cyclopean Tomb.author: Mode
306: Cyclopean Tomb.text_parsed:
"Is it just me or is that Oracle text way more confusing than it needs to be?"

@lica_barelli: The second ability does sound really complicated at first, but i think there's no way to make the Oracle wording much simpler. In such peculiar cases, Alpha's common language might still help as reminder text, but just won't do it for such an elaborate game anymore because it's not distinct enough once there are card interactions.

It still does basically exactly what was originally inteded with " If Cyclopean Tomb is destroyed, remove one token of your choice each upkeep, returning that land to its original nature."
I'm pretty sure back then they didn't plan that you could still Stifle this ability, say, twenty turns after it went to the graveyard (long after it could remove any more mire counters), though :D

This ability is very uncommon or at least something you wouln't find on newer cards of this sort (that change particular array of permanents in some way) anymore. Instead of just 'disenchanting' all permanents that were influenced by it when it at once gets destroyed (e.g. like Corrosion - which again is a pretty old card by itself).
Yet Cyclopean Tomb slowly 'renaturalizes' only one each turn, which is the main reason for the confusing wording you need now in order to go with the rules that have become far more complex since Alpha.

The part with "remove all mire counters from a land that a mire counter was put onto with Cyclopean Tomb but that a mire counter has not been removed from with Cyclopean Tomb." is just making sure you can't pick a land during your upkeep that you already picked and doesn't have any counters left so by choosing it you could make sure other lands keep their mire counters forever.

"[i]Is it just me or is that Oracle text way more confusing than it needs to be?[/i]"

314: Icy Manipulator.text_posted: If [autocard]R&D's Secret Lair[/autocard] is in play, you [u]don't[/u] have to tap Mono Artifacts to use them.

314: Icy Manipulator.author: Lateralis0ne
314: Icy Manipulator.text_parsed:
Kitsune:

I think you do. Even as you play the card as written, with no errata from newer Oracle wordings, it's still considered a mono artifact, which by the rules of the game (including current) requires you to tap it to activate its ability. "Mono Artifact" might not mean anything to us nowadays, but its still relevant, as it takes the place of the tap symbol on this card (and others like it), and still count as "the way the card is written", errata or no.

315: Illusionary Mask.author: Phelplan
315: Illusionary Mask.text_parsed:
I think that I get what this card was meant to do. In which case the oracle text is messed up because the original text says "which you still have to spend" in regards to the card's casting cost.

Here is my interpretation of what this card should say:

:Play a creature spell face down as a 2/2 creature for . can be any part of that creature's casting cost, including 0. Colors in the casting cost may not be paid with inappropriate mana.
If a creature played face down with illusionary mask would deal or receive damage or be tapped, turn it face up and pay the remainder of the casting cost or sacrifice it.

My interpretation of what this card is meant to do:

Let's say you are playing green. You have this mask. You have three green mana available. You play a Sedge Scorpion and two Leatherback Baloths as face-down 2/2's all for . Next turn you have four green available and you state that you are attacking with a face down pair of the 2/2s (a baloth and a scorpion). Chaos ensues.

Wizards. Feel free to use this idea. Honestly, I think that this artifact could have a casting cost of and be perfectly fair. There could also be something in there about marking the card with colored counters to represent appropriate colored mana spent.

327: Mox Emerald.author: Pontiac
327: Mox Emerald.text_parsed:
A qucik FYI for those who don't know...

Moxes are power people, I've used them all, even before the restricting rules came out. Why are the moxes powerful? well on their own each mox is a boost for speed mana, which is powerful (not broken) what makes them broken is using all 5 in the same deck, plus those newer ones Diamond, Opal and the Chrome.

it's like playing 4 lightning bolts, you draw 1 and bolt the guy he's at 17 (still alot of life) you play another from your opening hand he's at 14, the more bolts the more effective the resault. The same goes for Moxes, when your opening hand is..

Mox Emerald, Any land, Mox Diamond, any other land, Wheel of Fortune, (and 2 whatever cards, could be counterspell and Force of Will)

you drop a land, drop the Emerald, drop the Diamond and ditch a land, tap them play Wheel

You just hosed your opponent, they discard 7 and you both draw 7 new cards. At this point you've only played 2 moxes out of 8 (1 copy of each in the deck plus a Lotus) what are your chances of drawing more? pretty good, you can also draw more draw cards like Timetwister, Windfall, Memory Jar, Ancestral Recall plus you could be playing with Lotus Pedal, Dark Ritual's and such for even more lightspeed mana.

Moxes are called power for a reason. And for anyone wanting to say "oh those opening hands don't happen" guess again, rare opening hands were when we didn't do anything broken on the first turn.

But I tend to like Sapphire Mox because it provides blue with ramping which blue seldom gets and its great for ramping Affinity. I don't hate cards for being expensive or over powerful, you just have to realize the power level of each card and say, "I don't have the money to make a deck like that" most players realize the unfairness when building a deck that costs $15 vs $500. the difference in price should indicate just how much more severe one deck is than the other.

335: Sol Ring.author: Cyleal
335: Sol Ring.text_parsed:
Cards should be rated on more than just power

There's Flavor, Power, Usability, and of course there's when a card is just a bit overpowered.

That said, Since the card is called Sol Ring I would've expected it to tap for white mana and it is a bit overpowered as far as things go. It absolutely breaks the mana curve. Compare with Ur Golem's Eye, Thran Dynamo and many other artifacts that tap for mana like this one.

I think it gets a 4.5. It just breaks the game. When there's a card that exists that's so good everyone NEEDS to be playing it, it shouldn't get a 5, but that's just my opinion.

338: The Hive.author: DrJack
338: The Hive.text_parsed:
I remember this card and we all enjoyed it. Yeah it was overcosted in its day, and is unplayable when compared to the power-creeped dreck being churned out monthly by the cardboard factory. But it was THE original token generator and had flavor where it lacked power.

Also, notice all the explanatory text? Back then they didn't require you to have encyclopedic knowledge of all the intricate rules as they do now with their terse, robotic lawyer-speak card text (with weirdo italicized reminder text that usually misses the mark widely with regard to clarifying the most confusing aspects of new cards).

340: Time Vault.author: jonb86
340: Time Vault.text_parsed:
If it was up to me, this is how Time Vault would be worded.

Time Vault Comes into the battlefield Tapped

If Time Vault would become untapped, if it is during your untap step, you may end your turn, if your turn ends this way, untap Time Vault, if your turn does not ended this way, Time Vault does not untap; your turn can only be ended this way once during your turn. Other replacement effects can not replace Time Vault's untapping.

{Tap}: Take an extra turn after this one.

No combos; you must, and I repeat YOU MUST skip a turn to take an extra turn, and it never ever untaps any other way but during your untap step effectively skipping your entire turn. This was probably the way it was intended to play when the card was designed but it was resorceful Magic players that found ways to manipulate it; at first using series/stack tricks with the way extra turns were taken to take their turns before the skipped turn and later using untap ability tricks to take unlimited turns.

I really hate "preventable combos" and Time Vault along with Flash are two preventable combo cards I wish they'd errata correctly so they don't have to be banned because of turn 1 and turn 2, two card combos.

340: Time Vault.author: tavaritz
340: Time Vault.text_parsed:
The original wording of Time Vault is:

Tap to gain an additional turn after the current one. Time Vault doesn't untap normally during untap phase; to untap it, you must skip a turn. Time Vault begins tapped.

It clearly states that you must skip a turn to untap Time Vault.

Why not word it so that no other untapping won't work. This is my take of the Oracle wording:

Time Vault enters the battlefield tapped.
Time Vault doesn't untap unless you skip your turn. You can only skip your turn when your turn is about to begin. If you would begin your turn while Time Vault is tapped, you may skip that turn instead. If you do, untap Time Vault.
Tap: Take an extra turn after this one.
340: Time Vault.text_posted:
The original wording of Time Vault is:

Tap to gain an additional turn after the current one. Time Vault doesn't untap normally during untap phase; to untap it, you must skip a turn. Time Vault begins tapped.

It clearly states that you [b]must[/b] skip a turn to untap Time Vault.

Why not word it so that no other untapping won't work. This is my take of the Oracle wording:

Time Vault enters the battlefield tapped.
Time Vault doesn't untap unless you skip your turn. You can only skip your turn when your turn is about to begin. If you would begin your turn while Time Vault is tapped, you may skip that turn instead. If you do, untap Time Vault.
Tap: Take an extra turn after this one.

340: Time Vault.author: DarthParallax
340: Time Vault.text_parsed:
This card is really dumb. No for real it's horribly dumb.

Know how dumb this card is?

People just don't respect Timetwister much anymore, though they still like Wheel of Fortune which is the exact same thing in a different color, and they consider Wheel to be the postercard of that effect now.

This is because Timetwister was at first given the prestige of being one of the "Power Nine". To be Power Nine you have to be:

1) Completely utterly undercosted for your effect
2) Actually broken in Tournament play, so that Banning and Restricting in one or both Eternal Formats makes more than just sense- it sounds like the only way to keep the formats healthy.
Cards like Bazaar of Baghdad and Library of Alexandria have been hotly debated as possible "Power Tenth" cards.
3) The final requirement to be really accepted as Power turned out to be: Must be from Alpha, and have the full prestige of "Developers were all on coke back then" assumptions as the only sorry excuses for its existence.

There is more consensus that Time Vault is actually legitly a Power Card than any other card not in the Original List than any other, which is where I decided that people are giving extra weight to 'is from Alpha' from. It took Timetwister's place, and no matter HOW GOOD Timetwister IS and IS KNOWN to be, it was once a POWER NINE card, and has lost that highest place in MAGIC player's eyes, and now will forever have to deal with that affecting how people evaluate it, resulting in it being downgraded to be thought of as "Wheel of Fortune but Blue" RATHER than Wheel being "Timetwister but Red".

The next time any of the 5 Moxen or Black Lotus or Ancestral Recall or Time Walk get a call saying "Sorry, we don't think you're THAT great anymore because of this guy", you will have your answer to which card has had more impact than Time Vault. Jace, the Mind Sculptor is nowhere near close at all, he's practically a joke.
MANA DRAIN is a joke when you set THAT kind of bar.



ATTENTION WIZARDS: STOP MESSING WITH TIME!

340: Time Vault.author: mtkaim
340: Time Vault.text_parsed: @DarthParallax: Have you actually read what Timetwister does and what Wheel of Fortune does? If you have, how can you say that they are the exact same thing, because they have totally different effects? And also if you have not read hte cards, you also should not be able to claim that they are the same thing. The only similar thing is that both make all players draw 7 cards. Wheel makes them also discard their hand before drawing, whereas Timetwister doesn't discard anything (matters for example if Megrim is in play) but all players shuffle their hands and graveyards into their libraries, so the main idea is graveyard recursion.

344: Bad Moon.author: nerothewizard
344: Bad Moon.text_parsed:
RANDOM CARD REVIEW - 12/19/12

Don't go out tonight...it's bound to take your life.

Seriously, though, this is a classic. In the same vein as Crusade, it's always interesting to have an anthem effect that may boost your opponent's guys as well. Often, it's worth the risk, and sometimes, it's just fun to include cards like this in a multiplayer game for hilarious moments. (A 2-Headed Giant with both players running black? 4 of this, please.) It's also rare altogether to see a black anthem that's not tribe-specific, so this card has a lot of versatility. An all-around solid card.

Now, about the art. Some people might vote it down for the silly-looking face on the moon, but I think it adds a ton of character to this card. Other that that little detail, the art is very simple and straightforward, with a nice aesthetic provided by the creepy trees on either side and the silhouette of the mountain range underneath the cloud-covered sky. While those aspects of the art are pleasant, what really makes the card stand out in the art department is definitely that subtle but oh-so-important detail of the moon's face. It ties in with the title of the card, and it gives the card more personality. I personally like it very much, as I like the card as a whole.

FINAL RATING: 4.5/5

354: Demonic Hordes.author: Laguz
354: Demonic Hordes.text_parsed:
If you take the eras they were legal in into consideration, the hordes are better than helldozer, and much more so.

Helldozer did not have dark ritual available, but the hordes did, and thus insured that the opponent would never have more than three lands in play. The hordes also had instill energy, which let it destroy two lands a turn, or destroy one and attack. If that weren't enough, the only removal spell that could kill the hordes was swords to plowshares, but there were many more ways to kill Helldozer by the time Ravnica came around.

Also, the hordes have the flavor, the art and the nostalgia.
354: Demonic Hordes.text_posted:
If you take the eras they were legal in into consideration, the hordes are better than [autocard]helldozer[/autocard], and much more so. 

Helldozer did not have [autocard]dark ritual[/autocard] available, but the hordes did, and thus insured that the opponent would never have more than three lands in play. The hordes also had [autocard]instill energy[/autocard], which let it destroy two lands a turn, or destroy one and attack. If that weren't enough, the only removal spell that could kill the hordes was [autocard]swords to plowshares[/autocard], but there were many more ways to kill Helldozer by the time Ravnica came around.

Also, the hordes have the flavor, the art and the nostalgia.

Blue or white player (bowp): I steal your Demonic Hordes, hah!
You: ...
bowps upkeep
Demonic Hordes: Give me my black mana.
bowp: What? Oh, I don't have any.

bowp: Calm down man!

Demonic Hordes: Whoops, I destroyed it. NOW GIVE ME MY BLACK MANA OR YOU KNOW WHAT HAPPENS NEXT UPKEEP!

355: Demonic Tutor.author: keeds4
355: Demonic Tutor.text_parsed: It was art like that the art used for this card that made Christian groups rise up in arms. Putting pentagrams on cards is a good way to weed out a lot of potential players and lead many to focus on dumb ancillary issues instead of what Magic: The Gathering offers: creative deck-building, sound strategy, a developed sense of rules, and a means by which awkward teens can interact with each other without having to use a computer. That's just my opinion.

364: Lich.author: Kurhan
364: Lich.text_parsed:
this + dovescape + pestilence + Darien, king of kjeldoran

....mmmmmm.......

1) cant lose for having too little life
2) no spells can be cast other than creatures, leaving MOST ways to kill this useless
3) anytime you take damage you get a token that you can then sacrifice
4) pestilence deals damage to everything on the field, takes care of those pesky birds if you cant get through them.

Black + White combo for near immortality and it leaves you open to beat your opponent to death with either doves or pestilence them to death (while leaving one creature on the field).

365: Lord of the Pit.author: Morgaledh
365: Lord of the Pit.text_parsed:
This is the card that made me want to start playing this game. First, I just love saying "Lord of the Pit." Then there's the artwork... nothing like it, man. As far as the suicide aspect, dying to this thing because I wasn't able to control it was so flavorful that it was almost ok. I mean, I started playing D&D/AD&D back in 81, so I got that if you summoned a demon and screwed around with it, you'd die. No cacodemon spells here. And when I didn't die, but used my summoned fiend to crush my opponent? All was right with the world.

This card isn't about what is better and what is worse. This card is about, well, this card. And it has to be a 5/5, because this is Magic, and it's a Lord of the Pit.

365: Lord of the Pit.author: Radagast
365: Lord of the Pit.text_parsed:
Despite all the more powerful creatures printed since then, they still haven't printed anything directly superior to this guy. Other demons may be larger, smaller, have different sacrifice effects, or be easier to control but then tap down when you fail them, but Lord of the Pit is still rather unique for his size, casting cost, and abilities (for good or for bad.)

Hard to use effectively, but not unplayable if you can get him to work since a 7/7 flying black trampler is not to be laughed at.

370: Paralyze.author: majinara
370: Paralyze.text_parsed:
I wonder why they don't reprint it. Is it on a reserved list?

Even for todays standards it seems ok. Not awesome, but definately playable. For one lousy mana you can tap an annoying creature, and forcing the opponent to pay four mana each time to untap it is quite a lot. Not to mention your opponent faces a difficult decision: your opponent has to decide whether to pay four mana or not, before he draws a card in his turn. So if he pays four, he might not have the mana to play whatever he draws.

Sure, if an opponent has 10 or more mana or so available, it doesn't do that much. But still, I think it's a nice card.

390: Ancestral Recall.author: Enchantment_Removal
390: Ancestral Recall.text_parsed:
The conundrum:

There exist an Island, Cloud Sprite, Unsummon, and this here Ancestral Recall.

Without the Island, you can't do anything; so you lose.
Without the Cloud Sprite, you can't win; so you lose.
If your opponent matches your Cloud Sprite with their Raging Goblin, you lose if you don't Unsummon it at least once while it is attacking.

As you are well aware, this is an example of a moment in a game of Magic. Games are very different yet are kind of similar in a way. This conundrum has a second clause: (Prerequisite: each player untaps their stuff at the beginning of each turn and draws one card each turn- you knew that)

A player must invest a card and/or the untap of a creature/land (all of which are henceforth deemed 'resources') to subtract the other player's cards and/or life total.
At the smallest amount of 'resource', a unit of 'resource' either subtracts from the other player's cards or their life total. Remember that I am speaking on the fundamental levels. The same goes for adding cards/life to you.

Magic is so cleverly and beautifully designed with the interactions between cards; and so the card game is indeed a card game. With the previous two clauses we have the last:

Each of your cards are necessary to for you to win. Same for the opponent. All cards are lost/neutralized when each player has each card. So there forms a synchronized cycle between both players. Everything evens out.
If you were to Ancestral Recall to get to your cards faster/sooner than your opponent, you would have an unmatched Cloud Sprite or an additional Unsummon, ultimately causing you to win.

Another way to phrase above is that the Ancestral Recall drew into your (addition) Island, Cloud Sprite, and Unsummon that are necessary to win.
So, people beg the question, which card won you the game? OR which card is better?
It is a divine mystery. The Storm Crow trollers may unknowingly speak an ancient truth.

I personally belong to the religion of card draw, for it does not matter whether or not your library has the cards to win unless you draw into them.

If your opponent matches your Cloud Sprite with their [autocard multiverseid="14617"]Raging Goblin[/autocard], you lose if you don't Unsummon it at least once while it is attacking.[/i]

As you are well aware, this is an [u]example[/u] of a moment in a game of Magic. Games are very different yet are kind of similar in a way. This conundrum has a second clause: (Prerequisite: each player untaps their stuff at the beginning of each turn and draws one card each turn- you knew that)

[i]A player must invest a card and/or the untap of a creature/land (all of which are henceforth deemed 'resources') to subtract the other player's cards and/or life total.
At the smallest amount of 'resource', a unit of 'resource' either subtracts from the other player's cards or their life total.[/i] Remember that I am speaking on the fundamental levels. The same goes for adding cards/life to you.

Magic is so cleverly and beautifully designed with the interactions between cards; and so the card game is indeed a card game. With the previous two clauses we have the last:

[i]Each of your cards are necessary to for you to win. Same for the opponent. All cards are lost/neutralized when each player has each card. So there forms a synchronized cycle between both players. Everything evens out.
If you were to Ancestral Recall to get to your cards faster/sooner than your opponent, you would have an unmatched Cloud Sprite or an additional Unsummon, ultimately causing you to win.[/i]

Another way to phrase above is that the Ancestral Recall drew into your (addition) Island, Cloud Sprite, and Unsummon that are necessary to win.
So, people beg the question, [b]which card won you the game?[/b] OR [b]which card is better?[/b]
It is a divine mystery. The [autocard multiverseid="83282"]Storm Crow[/autocard] trollers may unknowingly speak an ancient truth.

I personally belong to the religion of card draw, for it does not matter whether or not your library has the cards to win unless you draw into them.

390: Ancestral Recall.author: EGarrett01
390: Ancestral Recall.text_parsed:
@Enchantment_Removal

The answer of what card "wins you the game" becomes much clearer when we place ourselves in a two player game. Our opponent ALSO has cards that will lower our life total or draw himself extra cards. Now we can see that we win when we can UNBALANCE the situation and draw more cards or do more damage to him then he can do to us.

Thus, it becomes clear that a card that allows you to easily draw far more cards than your opponent will be the one that is most directly responsible for you being able to win.

Thus...the power of Ancestral Recall.

It's quite clear Wizards had yet to figure out what they were doing back when they were first getting started.

417: Psionic Blast.author: Cyberium
417: Psionic Blast.text_parsed: Many people wonder why Psionic Blast is consider more powerful than Char. The answer is simple. Blue, by tradition, isn't the color of aggression. It's on the other side of Red and Green and thus were designed to be more passive and controlling. Psionic Blast is one of the exceptions where planeswalkers could do direct damage to kill a creature or opponent. Combine with other blue control cards, PB is very dangerous, compare to Char is already in a damage-abundant color. Last but not least, there are also way fewer creatures with protection from blue than red.

425: Thoughtlace.author: A3Kitsune
425: Thoughtlace.text_parsed: Magic has an abundance of cards that care about color, but is short on cards that change something's color. The last ones printed were the Wisp cycle in Shadowmore, and they both only affected creatures and only lasted a turn. How about bringing back the best in color-change, the original lace cycle (only this time at uncommon)? Or, next time there is a gold block, a cycle of hybrid laces that make whatever they change both their colors?
425: Thoughtlace.text_posted: Magic has an abundance of cards that care about color, but is short on cards that change something's color. The last ones printed were the Wisp cycle in Shadowmore, and they both only affected creatures and only lasted a turn. How about bringing back the best in color-change, the original lace cycle (only this time at uncommon)? Or, next time there is a gold block, a cycle of hybrid laces that make whatever they change both their colors?

425: Thoughtlace.author: tavaritz
425: Thoughtlace.text_parsed: Laces are so specific in use that you don't want multiples in sealed environment. Thus they must remain rare.
425: Thoughtlace.text_posted: Laces are so specific in use that you don't want multiples in sealed environment. Thus they must remain rare.

425: Thoughtlace.author: DarthParallax
425: Thoughtlace.text_parsed:
As far as I can tell, the Laces break down like this:

Red & Green: I am unaware of any 'color matters' cards that you would want to change specifically to R or G for. I especially doubt you'd want to spend a card to do it.
White: Cards like Crusade and Honor of the Pure make the idea of changing something to be white something I might actually want to do, but I wouldn't spend a card on it.
Black & Blue: Terror. Doom Blade. I can actually see an environment where it would be o.k. to draft Deathlace and not feel terrible...if it was an uncommon, not a rare. Turning something Black to keep it safe from Black cards is a wierd thing to be doing with...black mana....since you are probably already running black creatures...but at the same time, it doesn't sound useless. Obviously you turn something Blue if you want everyone at the table to immediately be overcome with hatred for it and try to destroy it.


Also- this is a Wierd Alpha Blue Rare. Those can be dangerous. Let's ban it in Vintage just in case. :p
425: Thoughtlace.text_posted:
As far as I can tell, the Laces break down like this: 

[i][u]Red & Green[/u][/i]: I am unaware of any 'color matters' cards that you would want to change specifically to R or G for. I especially doubt you'd want to spend a card to do it.
[i][u]White[/u][/i]: Cards like [autocard]Crusade[/autocard] and Honor of the Pure make the idea of changing something to be white something I might actually want to do, but I wouldn't spend a card on it.
[i][u]Black & Blue[/u][/i]: [autocard]Terror[/autocard]. Doom Blade. I can actually see an environment where it would be o.k. to draft Deathlace and not feel terrible...if it was an uncommon, not a rare. Obviously you turn something Blue if you want everyone at the table to immediately be overcome with hatred for it and try to destroy it.


Also- this is a Wierd Alpha Blue Rare. Those can be dangerous. Let's ban it in Vintage just in case. :p

427: Timetwister.author: AmericanVigor
427: Timetwister.text_parsed:
It's alright, but it's overrated.

In the modern era, I find it more based on tradition than functionality that this is considered part of the Power Nine.

While it indeed has its extremely effective uses, it's got a few serious functional downsides.

If your opponent has many less cards in his or her hand than you do, and especially if your opponent has greater card advantage on the battlefield, Timetwister could benefit your opponent much more than it might benefit you. In fact, you have the potential to find yourself in a worse position than when you started.

Black Lotus, the moxes and Time Walk all benefit you without your opponent having any chance of benefiting more from them more than you. Ancestral Recall is almost always used by its caster to draw cards rather than forcing his or her opponent to draw cards, and so it basically fits in the same boat as Black Lotus, the moxes and Time Walk.

But what about Timetwister? It not only has a higher mana cost than the others, but it's the only one of the Power Nine that could potentially put you at a significant disadvantage to your opponents.

Many players value not having to take chances when they don't have to, and I believe Timetwister adds unnecessary risk.

427: Timetwister.author: Pontiac
427: Timetwister.text_parsed:
to all of you who are stating that Timetwister is overhyped, I highly doubt your ever owned and played with one. In a deck with Windfall, Wheel of Fortune, and Memory Jar, with the rest of the power and other fast mana like Vaults, Sol Ring and Dark Rituals this card spanks people, you cast it with ease. I spent many a first turns droping a blue dual and two moxes, or a mox and a sol ring or Mana Crypt or whatever, I then cast Twister refill my hand and possibly do more right away with other moxen floating around, at worst case I drew force of wills, counters and drains, I still had control.

at 2U to cast Timetwister can ruin someones day, I remember watching an opponent mulligan his hand down to 5 cards to get his combo in his hand, so I Timetwistered and he folded, true story.

427: Timetwister.author: N3rf
427: Timetwister.text_parsed:
The way it got explained to me the Power 9 is called that way, because no matter what deck you are playing, what combo or tactic, if you could afford these 9 cards, they would improve your deck. I'm not sure if thats why they are called the p9, but it explained the reason why they are often mentioned as a set of cards, why this card is included and why a card like wheel of fortune is not.
All decks that include p9 have dual lands and all of them splash blue (for the p9, force of will etc), so including timetwister over the functionally near-identical wheel of fortune (graveyard recursion in a 0-4 turn format is rather meh), makes a lot more sense.

What it does, is refill your hand AND disrupt the opponent's hand in a format where doing either of those in the first two turns is as game breaking as taking an extra turn or getting a 0 mana artifact out that produces mana. Read Pontiac's comment.

This card deserves its status. They may be cards that individually could beat it (library of alexandria springs to mind to me), but no other card is an auto include as fast as this one, except ofcourse the rest of its mythical set, Power 9.

428: Twiddle.author: kitsunewarlock
428: Twiddle.text_parsed: A classic. It protects you from damage, gives you a blocker, lets you use that creature's tap ability twice, ramps your mana with cards like Tolarian Academy, Sol Ring or just Tron. It protects you from counter-spells by tapping out your opponent's last island, you can put it on Scepter to get an Icy Manipulator on crack. It lets you use your artifact again and de-activates artifacts like Winter Orb or Howling Mine. There have been many variations of this card, many of which are a tad stronger. But Twiddle will always maintain its status as the first.

430: Vesuvan Doppelganger.author: Amorgan
430: Vesuvan Doppelganger.text_parsed:
@Mike-C


Quoting the Ruling,"9/16/2007
Although Vesuvan Doppelganger's triggered ability is targeted, its "as enters the battlefield" ability is not. "

Since the enters the field trigger doesn't "target" anything, that means that creatures with "Protection" can be copied when it enters the battlefield, but not after Because "Vesuvan Doppelganger's triggered ability is targeted"

so Progenitus the 10/10 with "Protection from Everything" Can be copied when Vesuvan Doppelganger comes into play (just like Clone, but unlike Cackling Counterpart which legitimately has to "Target"

Anyways this card is one of the original "copy cards" and the only one that doesn't copy the color of the Copied card

5/5 for originality and being special for so long

Aside from doubling tricks (doubling and then doubling again, etc.) this card isn't really that nasty by today's standards. Sure, doubling power and giving trample is great, but the creature would probably just eat instant speed removal anyway. Better than Giant Growth on the attack, but weaker in some ways since the creature dies at EoT.

IMHO, I'd like to see them reprint this... I wonder if it would even see much play outside of Limited if they did. Good card, though.

437: Birds of Paradise.author: liir007
437: Birds of Paradise.text_parsed:
Card of the Day - Friday, March 29, 2002
The Birds have been one of the staples of the game since it began, but they were created as an afterthought. Their art was originally supposed to be for Tropical Island, but the bird was too prominent. So Richard Garfield created a card just for the art, and it ended up being the most versatile mana-producing creature ever.
--Also the creature type was 'Mana Birds', modern versions are just 'Bird'

438: Camouflage.author: longwinded
438: Camouflage.text_parsed: Morph means that the attackers can't be "face down" any more. If you attacked with a face-up morph creature, you would get another activation out of him. If you attack with a face-down morph creature, you get a free, involuntary activation. That's why this is now "sort into piles and have opponent block a pile at random."

442: Elvish Archers.author: Ibn_Shisha
442: Elvish Archers.text_parsed: @Eved; How do we know what anyone said at the Battle of Thermopylae? Herodotus may have used creative license in Histories vol VII.
442: Elvish Archers.text_posted: @Eved; How do we know what anyone said at the Battle of Thermopylae?  Herodotus may have used creative license in [i]Histories vol VII[/i].

442: Elvish Archers.author: Drvst
442: Elvish Archers.text_parsed:
The flavor text is indeed a reference to Hdt. 7.226.1. "ὡς ἐπεὰν οἱ βάρβαροι ἀπίωσι τὰ τοξεύματα, τὸν ἥλιον ὑπὸ τοῦ πλήθεος τῶν ὀιστῶν ἀποκρύπτουσι: τοσοῦτο πλῆθος αὐτῶν εἶναι. " It is tucked inside a whole lot of indirect discourse.... so it turns out Herodotus heard about this guy named Dieneces who heard from the Trachinians that "When the barbarians shot their arrows, that they hid the sun by the great number of arrows... so large was the number of arrows." Translated by me.
Cool, eh? 5 stars for a Herodotus reference.
442: Elvish Archers.text_posted:

455: Kudzu.author: Chamale
455: Kudzu.text_parsed:
It looks good at first glance, but then I realized the problem.

For 3 mana, you practically destroy the land - since the controller would be foolish to tap that land anymore. However, they still have the option of using that land later if they really need to. A good player will be able to realize when it's safe to start losing the lands attached to Kudzu. For 2G, simply use Ice Storm, with which you can destroy a land for certain.

Obviously needs to be run against the right deck and it won't work against most, but man, being able to counter black spells (not as necessary with all the shroud/troll shroud in green, but kill spells are anathema to many mono green decks) repeatedly as long as you have a few spare mana is crazy!  I can actually see sideboarding 2-3 of these for casual games depending on your playgroup or running a few in some legacy environments.  You're not going to use it that often, but it can just wreck some of green's strongest counters.

459: Living Artifact.author: Radagast

The flavor text is horrible, but made up for by the art.

473: Verduran Enchantress.author: DrJack
473: Verduran Enchantress.text_parsed:
Wow. I think this is the first time I've ever come across a set of comments for a card, and agreed with every single one of them. (as of this writing, 10-04-2013)
Yes, we're all kindered spirits here. I wonder if we ever met at a Magic tournament at some point in 1994-95.

I had the old Collector's Edition set during my younger years, and I spent hours entranced by the artwork. I was particularly stunned by the artwork for Kev Brockschmidt's Verduran Enchantress. It was cards like that which drew me into the game. There hasn't been any art in M:tG with that kind of beauty in a great while. Yes, while looking through this Collector's set, I could tell by the amazing artwork, and the graceful way the cards interacted with one another, with the sensible, down-to-earth wording, that I was going to really enjoy this game. For me, the Alpha/Beta/Unlimited edition will always be true Magic.

@ LateralisOne - you're not the only one who didn't like the "Pokemon Star-Trek" style change that came with Mirrodin. At the time when I saw them, I thought to myself "I'm glad my days of paying money for Magic cards are long over".

@ SlackWareWolf - I know what you mean. Mid 1994 is when I got into the game, and I noticed that the cards actually *smelled* quite nice back then. I never opened any Arabian Nights boosters, but did open several Antiquities and a good bunch of Legends and Revised. I recall that Fallen Empires boosters smelled kind of bad, and some people on the old Usenet even commented that the bad smell could have contributed to the set's unpopularity. A funny thought... but who knows. :-)

475: Wall of Ice.author: Kryptnyt
475: Wall of Ice.text_parsed:
Dead Soldiers (which are white) are often black Zombies (enemy colored)
Blue's enemy colors are green and red. When Red fights against water, water's "corpse" is steam. When Green (nature) does battle with water, it is sometimes sucked up into tree roots, or into the ground. But sometimes when weather (an early domain of green) gets involved, "killing" water will result in ice.

In other words, this is the green equivalent of a zombie; a perversion of one of its enemy's threats turned against them.

djflo- somewhere along the line, Green lost its domain of "weather" except for windstorms (Hurricane, Arashi, the sky asunder... windstorm). Tsunami is a green card because it is a powerful natural force, rather than a literal attack by water.

Nowadays, this would be blue - wall of frost. Blue has assumed control over ice completely. Green no longer perverts the enemy's corpse. Black has assumed control over reanimation. White has some reanimation spells, but they all have flavor indicating that it's actually a sort of rebirth, or return to life. The very, very rare time green gets reanimation, it comes in the form of reincarnation.

The color pie is much more defined today, and also much more restrictive. Back in Alpha, any color could be justified doing anything. No lie.

497: Goblin King.author: Aquillion
497: Goblin King.text_parsed:
@A3Kitsune: No, originally, he didn't have the 'goblin' creature type; he had the 'goblin king' creature type. Under the early rules of the game, a creature's type consisted only of the entire phrase after "summon" on their text, not the individual words of that phrase, so Goblin King didn't affect himself. (Notice how the original wording doesn't say "other goblins" -- that was added when he was changed into a goblin in the grand creature type update, as the rulings on him note.)

This was a huge problem for early goblin decks, since they had searchers but couldn't use them to search up the kings. It also meant multiple kings wouldn't buff each other; now they do.

(Thankfully, goblin chirurgeon could regenerate non-goblins; it only require a goblin to sacrifice.)

You wouldn't believe how awesome old Magic cards that nobody plays and 'dies to x' can get once you read the novels.

Specifically, the story of Krieg and Gatha was a pure joy to read in the book 'Bloodlines', part of Artifacts Cycle II.

Basically, the Keldons are somewhere inbetween the Spartans from 300 (ahistorical exaggerations and all), crossed with THOR from...Thor. and the Avengers movie, lol.

"We drank, we fought, we killed 10,000 men in a bloody savage night of blind revelry and rage, we made our ancestors proud! THIS! IS! KELDON!!!!!!!!!!!!"

512: Red Elemental Blast.author: DarthParallax
512: Red Elemental Blast.text_parsed:
Dear Gatherer: please comment on my following proposal for a cycle


White Energy Blast-- 1WW
Instant- Rare
Counter target black or red spell, or
destroy target black or red permanenet.

Blue Energy Blast 1UU
Instant- Rare
Counter target red or green spell, or
Destroy target red or green permanent.

Black Energy Blast 1BB
Instant- Rare
Counter target green or white spell, or
destroy target green or white permanent.

Red Energy Blast-- 1RR
Instant- Rare
Counter target white or blue spell, or
destroy target white or blue permanent.

Green Energy Blast-- 1GG
Instant- Rare
Counter target black or red spell, or
destroy target black or red permanent.

Up the cost, change 'Elemental' to 'Energy', and make this a cycle.
The Design idea is that a hate cycle should exist that allows other colors access to spell-countering.
It works on the Red Elemental Blast and doesn't ruin the game- I think it can work in other colors, too.
*Blue should remain dominant, and this should be the only countering some colors get. (Green, Red)

The Development reason for the rarity is for Limited's sake, and because the effect
is quite powerful, but a staple for deck construction, so Mythic isn't right.
The converted casting cost is 3 because Wizards deems that is where Cancel should sit,
but the extra line of text makes all of these about twice as powerful as Cancel.

The Creative reasoning that allows Vorthos to get his head around multi-colored countering is that
each color has Wizards. The Wizard creature type, like Humans, is something that they all have in common, even though Blue Wizards are much more common. Wizards throw around brightly colored
'fireworks' spells all the time, and countering is the best thing I know to represent that.

Question: Does anyone think these cards would see play at 2CC? Or is that too much to ask because of the conditionality? At 2CC, they might be o.k. at uncommon....

The only thing I worry about is that this cycle might be THE perfect 'Hate' cycle, so good it renders other concepts for Hating obsolete. Question: Is that necessarily a bad thing? Although the entire Alpha set has finally rotated with the removal of Giant Spider from M12, I think the original idea of having some cards be constant, perennial classic mainstays of the game is a good one.

Is this too egregious a breaking of the color pie to be allowed, or do I make a decent case that this could be something to consider? Perhaps not in Standard...but what about future Planechase, Archenemy, or Commander decks?

528: Armageddon.author: DarthParallax
528: Armageddon.text_parsed:
I'm considering making my own 'edited' version of Beta set in MSE.

Goal is to Make it
a) possible to play Limited with
b) possible for Constructed decks to not have to choose between 'broken or suck'
c) add things like Legendary that should have been in the game from the beginning
d) not only weaken some of the cards that need weakening (Balance, anyone?), but also push, just slightly, cards that deserve to look more impressive. Thinking especially about Lord of the Pit, Shivan Dragon, and Serra Angel.
It will be very difficult to keep them in-flavor, make them 'dressed to impress', and ALSO avoid making overpushed designs like Baneslayer. But if I can do it, I think the 're-vamped' cards could be aMAZing.

So in regards to Armageddon--I think it is actually a card that would be ok to leave almost as is. The effect can be a game-winner, can even be back-breaking, but is not particularly vicious: i.e., there are many options that you can use to play around it, including countermagic, tapping all your lands in response to play a big red burn spell, or hoping you developed your board enough to win anyway.
Change from 3W->3WW or 3WWW. and I think it's not that bad. Seriously. Compare it to some Mythics today, and the mere resolution of the spell doesn't mean autolosing.

534: Blue Ward.author: car2n
534: Blue Ward.text_parsed: The pop-art (yet neo-minimalist) etchings of Blue Ward,  liegemen to the Pollackian legacy, question its own raison d'etre. Is it visual tropes? Is it self-conscious (self-mocking/self-loathing) po-mo nombrilisme? Or is it simply (and solely) a stochastic snapshot sans lexical basis? The color ward cycle can best be examined as artistic interventions against the oppressive humor archetype, whereas the unappealingly desperate musings of Dan Frazier's eponymous series are truly indebted to Jenny Holzer’s oeuvre. Or, as Baudrillard and Guillaume so succinctly state, "What is produced with the romantic turn…is…the…play of…masculine hysteria…of …sexual paradigms that once again must be reinserted in the more general and universal context of a change in the paradigms of otherness."
534: Blue Ward.text_posted: The pop-art (yet neo-minimalist) etchings of Blue Ward,  liegemen to the Pollackian legacy, question its own raison d'etre. Is it visual tropes? Is it self-conscious (self-mocking/self-loathing) po-mo nombrilisme? Or is it simply (and solely) a stochastic snapshot sans lexical basis? 536: Circle of Protection: Black.author: SarcasmElemental
536: Circle of Protection: Black.text_parsed:
I've read a lot of comments, A3kitsune, and if I had the option to delete just one comment on the entire gatherer site it would be yours right here.


AT marmaris76, He is being hyper critical of a fledgling company which hadn't found it's footing and yet still brought us the wonderful game we have today. Omitting this card effected the game for two months until they corrected with Beta. I don't know how many games were lost during those two months because of the absence of the card but the printing error has since built more character into the set and the history of magic itself.

Along with a few other mistakes, it really does show that Wizards messed up a lot towards the beginning. (They still do make a few mistakes every now and again, but small errors like on Walking Atlas and Wit's End aren't nearly as bad as omitting cards.)

I'm sorry, but I don't see how he's being "hyper critical." He's simply stating the facts: Wizards did not have their act together. Even if you do have a small point, saying that A3Kitsune's comment is the worst on all of Gatherer is far from correct.

563: Righteousness.author: Radagast
563: Righteousness.text_parsed:
Vastly under-rated back in the day. Way back when, White had a single card to effectively kill a creature - Swords to Plowshares. Sure, Wrath would clear the board, but that may not have been the goal.

This overlooked gem also effectively killed any attacking creature for 1 white mana. Yes, it only worked on attacks and only if you had a blocker, but still it wasn't a bad card at all.

These days, White gets a common-level way to neutralize creatures (Pacifism, etc.) in each set, so a card like this wouldn't see print.

This overlooked gem also effectively killed any attacking creature for 1 white mana. Yes, it only worked on attacks and only if you had a blocker, but still it wasn't a bad card at all.

These days, White gets a common-level way to neutralize creatures (Pacifism, etc.) in each set, so a card like this wouldn't see print.

563: Righteousness.author: ObsessedAddict
563: Righteousness.text_parsed:
White has very few combat tricks relative to the vast number that other colors have. This one is a great addition to this number though, as it has great flavor, has a very VERY affordable cost, and is not overpowered or underpowered in any way.

Also, Hold the Line.
Cheers.

This card has a 4.986 rating currently, and that is a serious accomplishment.
It's the closest you get to running Command Tower in Tournament Legal Black-Red decks.

The Power Nine are known quantities, but the Dual Lands are just as good, and arguably better since you can have 4 of them in your deck unlike Moxen, they make two colors, and if you are out to mana fix more than mana ramp, you'll be more likely to draw 1 of 4 of these than 1 of Mox Jet or Mox Ruby, especially with Fetch Lands.

583: Tundra.author: Zetan
583: Tundra.text_parsed:
@Verdande - Back then, they had no idea how big the game would become. Richard Garfield has said that he built the original sets (Alpha, Beta, etc) assuming that nobody would open more than a dozen or so packs. Essentially, the game was designed for sealed, not constructed (or at least not constructed as we know it today, where everyone has four of everything).

That's why those early sets had huge power level disparities at different rarities, because if you only have a dozen or so rares, it doesn't matter if one of them is completely busted. When someone in R&D asked, "Well, what if people are buying so many packs that they get enough of these cards to break the game?" Richard responded, "That could be a problem, but it would be a very good problem to have."
583: Tundra.text_posted:
@Verdande - Back then, they had no idea how big the game would become. Essentially, the game was designed for sealed, not constructed (or at least not constructed as we know it today, where everyone has four of everything).

That's why those early sets had huge power level disparities at different rarities, because if you only have a dozen or so rares, it doesn't matter if one of them is completely busted.  When someone in R&D asked, "Well, what if people are buying so many packs that they get enough of these cards to break the game?"
